verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 56:4
verses.text: And, although mankind have deeply fallen, and have been seduced by manifold errors, yet hast thou revealed a pure light in the person of thy Son, that the power of evil should not utterly prevail, and hast thus given testimony to all men concerning thyself.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 57:1
verses.text: Chapter LVIII.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 57:2
verses.text: —He glorifies him again for his Government of the Universe.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 57:3
verses.text: The truth of this is assured to us by thy works.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 57:4
verses.text: It is thy power which removes our guilt, and makes us faithful.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 57:5
verses.text: The sun and the moon have their settled course.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 57:6
verses.text: The stars move in no uncertain orbits round this terrestrial globe.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 57:7
verses.text: The revolution of the seasons recurs according to unerring laws.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 57:8
verses.text: The solid fabric of the earth was established by thy word: the winds receive their impulse at appointed times; and the course of the waters continues with ceaseless flow, the ocean is circumscribed by an immovable barrier, and whatever is comprehended within the compass of earth and sea, is all contrived for wondrous and important ends.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 57:9
verses.text: "Were it not so, were not all regulated by the determination of thy will, so great a diversity, so manifold a division of power, would unquestionably have brought ruin on the whole race and its affairs.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 57:10
verses.text: For those agencies which have maintained a mutual strife would thus have carried to a more deadly length that hostility against the human race which they even now exercise, though unseen by mortal eyes.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 58:1
verses.text: Chapter LIX.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 58:2
verses.text: —He gives Glory to God, as the Constant Teacher of Good.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 58:3
verses.text: "Abundant thanks, most mighty God, and Lord of all, be rendered to thee, that, by so much as our nature becomes known from the diversified pursuits of man, by so much the more are the precepts of thy divine doctrine confirmed to those whose thoughts are directed aright, and who are sincerely devoted to true virtue.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 58:4
verses.text: As for those who will not allow themselves to be cured of their error, let them not attribute this to any but themselves.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 58:5
verses.text: For that remedy which is of sovereign and healing virtue is openly placed within the reach of all.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 58:6
verses.text: Only let not any one inflict an injury on that religion which experience itself testifies to be pure and undefiled.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 58:7
verses.text: Henceforward, therefore, let us all enjoy in common the privilege placed within our reach, I mean the blessing of peace, endeavoring to keep our conscience pure from all that is contrary.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 59:1
verses.text: Chapter LX.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 59:2
verses.text: —An Admonition at the Close of the Edict, that No One should trouble his Neighbor.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 59:3
verses.text: "Once more, let none use that to the detriment of another which he may himself have received on conviction of its truth; but let every one, if it be possible, apply what he has understood and known to the benefit of his neighbor; if otherwise, let him relinquish the attempt.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 59:4
verses.text: For it is one thing voluntarily to undertake the conflict for immortality, another to compel others to do so from the fear of punishment.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 59:5
verses.text: "These are our words; and we have enlarged on these topics more than our ordinary clemency would have dictated, because we were unwilling to dissemble or be false to the true faith; and the more so, since we understand there are some who say that the rites of the heathen temples, and the power of darkness, have been entirely removed.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 59:6
verses.text: We should indeed have earnestly recommended such removal to all men, were it not that the rebellious spirit of those wicked errors still continues obstinately fixed in the minds of some, so as to discourage the hope of any general restoration of mankind to the ways of truth".

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 60:1
verses.text: Chapter LXI.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 60:2
verses.text: —How Controversies originated at Alexandria through Matters relating to Arius.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 60:3
verses.text: In this manner the emperor, like a powerful herald of God, addressed himself by his own letter to all the provinces, at the same time warning his subjects against superstitious error, and encouraging them in the pursuit of true godliness.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 60:4
verses.text: But in the midst of his joyful anticipations of the success of this measure, he received tidings of a most serious disturbance which had invaded the peace of the Church.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 60:5
verses.text: This intelligence he heard with deep concern, and at once endeavored to devise a remedy for the evil.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 60:6
verses.text: The origin of this disturbance may be thus described.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 60:7
verses.text: The people of God were in a truly flourishing state, and abounding in the practice of good works.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 60:8
verses.text: No terror from without assailed them, but a bright and most profound peace, through the favor of God, encompassed his Church on every side.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 60:9
verses.text: Meantime, however, the spirit of envy was watching to destroy our blessings, which at first crept in unperceived, but soon revelled in the midst of the assemblies of the saints.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 60:10
verses.text: At length it reached the bishops themselves, and arrayed them in angry hostility against each other, on pretense of a jealous regard for the doctrines of Divine truth.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 60:11
verses.text: Hence it was that a mighty fire was kindled as it were from a little spark, and which, originating in the first instance in the Alexandrian church, overspread the whole of Egypt and Libya, and the further Thebaid.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 60:12
verses.text: Eventually it extended its ravages to the other provinces and cities of the empire; so that not only the prelates of the churches might be seen encountering each other in the strife of words, but the people themselves were completely divided, some adhering to one faction and others to another.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 60:13
verses.text: Nay, so notorious did the scandal of these proceedings become, that the sacred matters of inspired teaching were exposed to the most shameful ridicule in the very theaters of the unbelievers.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 61:1
verses.text: Chapter LXII.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 61:2
verses.text: —Concerning the Same Arius, and the Melitians.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 61:3
verses.text: Some thus at Alexandria maintained an obstinate conflict on the highest questions.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 61:4
verses.text: Others throughout Egypt and the Upper Thebaid, were at variance on account of an earlier controversy: so that the churches were everywhere distracted by divisions.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 61:5
verses.text: The body therefore being thus diseased, the whole of Libya caught the contagion; and the rest of the remoter provinces became affected with the same disorder.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 61:6
verses.text: For the disputants at Alexandria sent emissaries to the bishops of the several provinces, who accordingly ranged themselves as partisans on either side, and shared in the same spirit of discord.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 62:1
verses.text: Chapter LXIII.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 62:2
verses.text: —How Constantine sent a Messenger and a Letter concerning Peace.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 62:3
verses.text: As soon as the emperor was informed of these facts, which he heard with much sorrow of heart, considering them in the light of a calamity personally affecting himself, he forthwith selected from the Christians in his train one whom he well knew to be approved for the sobriety and genuineness of his faith, and who had before this time distinguished himself by the boldness of his religious profession, and sent him to negotiate peace between the dissentient parties at Alexandria.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 62:4
verses.text: He also made him the bearer of a most needful and appropriate letter to the original movers of the strife: and this letter, as exhibiting a specimen of his watchful care over God's people, it may be well to introduce into this our narrative of his life.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 62:5
verses.text: Its purport was as follows.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 63:1
verses.text: Chapter LXIV.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 63:2
verses.text: —Constantine's Letter to Alexander the Bishop, and Arius the Presbyter.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 63:3
verses.text: "Victor Constantinus, Maximus Augustus, to Alexander and Arius.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 63:4
verses.text: "I call that God to witness, as well I may, who is the helper of my endeavors, and the Preserver of all men, that I had a twofold reason for undertaking that duty which I have now performed.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 64:1
verses.text: Chapter LXV.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 64:2
verses.text: —His Continual Anxiety for Peace.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 64:3
verses.text: "My design then was, first, to bring the diverse judgments formed by all nations respecting the Deity to a condition, as it were, of settled uniformity; and, secondly, to restore to health the system of the world, then suffering under the malignant power of a grievous distemper.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 64:4
verses.text: Keeping these objects in view, I sought to accomplish the one by the secret eye of thought, while the other I tried to rectify by the power of military authority.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 64:5
verses.text: For I was aware that, if I should succeed in establishing, according to my hopes, a common harmony of sentiment among all the servants of God, the general course of affairs would also experience a change correspondent to the pious desires of them all.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 65:1
verses.text: Chapter LXVI.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 65:2
verses.text: —That he also adjusted the Controversies which had arisen in Africa.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 65:3
verses.text: "Finding, then, that the whole of Africa was pervaded by an intolerable spirit of mad folly, through the influence of those who with heedless frivolity had presumed to rend the religion of the people into diverse sects; I was anxious to check this disorder, and could discover no other remedy equal to the occasion, except in sending some of yourselves to aid in restoring mutual harmony among the disputants, after I had removed that common enemy of mankind who had interposed his lawless sentence for the prohibition of your holy synods.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 66:1
verses.text: Chapter LXVII.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 66:2
verses.text: —That Religion began in the East.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 66:3
verses.text: "For since the power of Divine light, and the law of sacred worship, which, proceeding in the first instance, through the favor of God, from the bosom, as it were, of the East, have illumined the world, by their sacred radiance, I naturally believed that you would be the first to promote the salvation of other nations, and resolved with all energy of thought and diligence of enquiry to seek your aid.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 66:4
verses.text: As soon, therefore, as I had secured my decisive victory and unquestionable triumph over my enemies, my first enquiry was concerning that object which I felt to be of paramount interest and importance.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 67:1
verses.text: Chapter LXVIII.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 67:2
verses.text: —Being grieved by the Dissension, he counsels Peace.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 67:3
verses.text: "But, O glorious Providence of God! how deep a wound did not my ears only, but my very heart receive in the report that divisions existed among yourselves more grievous still than those which continued in that country! so that you, through whose aid I had hoped to procure a remedy for the errors of others, are in a state which needs healing even more than theirs.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 67:4
verses.text: And yet, having made a careful enquiry into the origin and foundation of these differences, I find the cause to be of a truly insignificant character, and quite unworthy of such fierce contention.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 67:5
verses.text: Feeling myself, therefore, compelled to address you in this letter, and to appeal at the same time to your unanimity and sagacity, I call on Divine Providence to assist me in the task, while I interrupt your dissension in the character of a minister of peace.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 67:6
verses.text: And with reason: for if I might expect, with the help of a higher Power, to be able without difficulty, by a judicious appeal to the pious feelings of those who heard me, to recall them to a better spirit, even though the occasion of the disagreement were a greater one, how can I refrain from promising myself a far easier and more speedy adjustment of this difference, when the cause which hinders general harmony of sentiment is intrinsically trifling and of little moment?.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 68:1
verses.text: Chapter LXIX.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 68:2
verses.text: —Origin of the Controversy between Alexander and Arius, and that these Questions ought not to have been discussed.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 68:3
verses.text: I understand, then, that the origin of the present controversy is this.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 68:4
verses.text: When you, Alexander, demanded of the presbyters what opinion they severally maintained respecting a certain passage in the Divine law, or rather, I should say, that you asked them something connected with an unprofitable question, then you, Arius, inconsiderately insisted on what ought never to have been conceived at all, or if conceived, should have been buried in profound silence.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 68:5
verses.text: Hence it was that a dissension arose between you, fellowship was withdrawn, and the holy people, rent into diverse parties, no longer preserved the unity of the one body.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 68:6
verses.text: Now, therefore, do ye both exhibit an equal degree of forbearance, and receive the advice which your fellow-servant righteously gives.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 68:7
verses.text: What then is this advice? It was wrong in the first instance to propose such questions as these, or to reply to them when propounded.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 68:8
verses.text: For those points of discussion which are enjoined by the authority of no law, but rather suggested by the contentious spirit which is fostered by misused leisure, even though they may be intended merely as an intellectual exercise, ought certainly to be confined to the region of our own thoughts, and not hastily produced in the popular assemblies, nor unadvisedly intrusted to the general ear.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 68:9
verses.text: For how very few are there able either accurately to comprehend, or adequately to explain subjects so sublime and abstruse in their nature? Or, granting that one were fully competent for this, how many people will he convince? Or, who, again, in dealing with questions of such subtle nicety as these, can secure himself against a dangerous declension from the truth? It is incumbent therefore on us in these cases to be sparing of our words, lest, in case we ourselves are unable, through the feebleness of our natural faculties, to give a clear explanation of the subject before us, or, on the other hand, in case the slowness of our hearers' understandings disables them from arriving at an accurate apprehension of what we say, from one or other of these causes the people be reduced to the alternative either of blasphemy or schism.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 69:1
verses.text: Chapter LXX.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 69:2
verses.text: —An Exhortation to Unanimity.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 69:3
verses.text: "Let therefore both the unguarded question and the inconsiderate answer receive your mutual forgiveness.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 69:4
verses.text: For the cause of your difference has not been any of the leading doctrines or precepts of the Divine law, nor has any new heresy respecting the worship of God arisen among you.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 69:5
verses.text: You are in truth of one and the same judgment: you may therefore well join in communion and fellowship.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 70:1
verses.text: Chapter LXXI.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 70:2
verses.text: —There should be no Contention in Matters which are in themselves of Little Moment.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 70:3
verses.text: "For as long as you continue to contend about these small and very insignificant questions, it is not fitting that so large a portion of God's people should be under the direction of your judgment, since you are thus divided between yourselves.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 70:4
verses.text: I believe it indeed to be not merely unbecoming, but positively evil, that such should be the case.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 70:5
verses.text: But I will refresh your minds by a little illustration, as follows.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 70:6
verses.text: You know that philosophers, though they all adhere to one system, are yet frequently at issue on certain points, and differ, perhaps, in their degree of knowledge: yet they are recalled to harmony of sentiment by the uniting power of their common doctrines.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 70:7
verses.text: If this be true, is it not far more reasonable that you, who are the ministers of the Supreme God, should be of one mind respecting the profession of the same religion? But let us still more thoughtfully and with closer attention examine what I have said, and see whether it be right that, on the ground of some trifling and foolish verbal difference between ourselves, brethren should assume towards each other the attitude of enemies, and the august meeting of the Synod be rent by profane disunion, because of you who wrangle together on points so trivial and altogether unessential? This is vulgar, and rather characteristic of childish ignorance, than consistent with the wisdom of priests and men of sense.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 70:8
verses.text: Let us withdraw ourselves with a good will from these temptations of the devil.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 70:9
verses.text: Our great God and common Saviour of all has granted the same light to us all.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 70:10
verses.text: Permit me, who am his servant, to bring my task to a successful issue, under the direction of his Providence, that I may be enabled, through my exhortations, and diligence, and earnest admonition, to recall his people to communion and fellowship.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 70:11
verses.text: For since you have, as I said, but one faith, and one sentiment respecting our religion, and since the Divine commandment in all its parts enjoins on us all the duty of maintaining a spirit of concord, let not the circumstance which has led to a slight difference between you, since it does not affect the validity of the whole, cause any division or schism among you.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 70:12
verses.text: And this I say without in any way desiring to force you to entire unity of judgment in regard to this truly idle question, whatever its real nature may be.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 70:13
verses.text: For the dignity of your synod may be preserved, and the communion of your whole body maintained unbroken, however wide a difference may exist among you as to unimportant matters.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 70:14
verses.text: For we are not all of us like-minded on every subject, nor is there such a thing as one disposition and judgment common to all alike.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 70:15
verses.text: As far, then, as regards the Divine Providence, let there be one faith, and one understanding among you, one united judgment in reference to God.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 70:16
verses.text: But as to your subtle disputations on questions of little or no significance, though you may be unable to harmonize in sentiment, such differences should be consigned to the secret custody of your own minds and thoughts.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 70:17
verses.text: And now, let the preciousness of common affection, let faith in the truth, let the honor due to God and to the observance of his law continue immovably among you.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 70:18
verses.text: Resume, then, your mutual feelings of friendship, love, and regard: restore to the people their wonted embracings; and do ye yourselves, having purified your souls, as it were, once more acknowledge one another.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 70:19
verses.text: For it often happens that when a reconciliation is effected by the removal of the causes of enmity, friendship becomes even sweeter than it was before.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 71:1
verses.text: Chapter LXXII.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 71:2
verses.text: —The Excess of his Pious Concern caused him to shed Tears; and his Intended Journey to the East was postponed because of These Things.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 71:3
verses.text: "Restore me then my quiet days, and untroubled nights, that the joy of undimmed light, the delight of a tranquil life, may henceforth be my portion.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 71:4
verses.text: Else must I needs mourn, with constant tears, nor shall I be able to pass the residue of my days in peace.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 71:5
verses.text: For while the people of God, whose fellow-servant I am, are thus divided amongst themselves by an unreasonable and pernicious spirit of contention, how is it possible that I shall be able to maintain tranquillity of mind? And I will give you a proof how great my sorrow has been on this behalf.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 71:6
verses.text: Not long since I had visited Nicomedia, and intended forthwith to proceed from that city to the East.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 71:7
verses.text: It was while I was hastening towards you, and had already accomplished the greater part of the distance, that the news of this matter reversed my plan, that I might not be compelled to see with my own eyes that which I felt myself scarcely able even to hear.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 71:8
verses.text: Open then for me henceforward by your unity of judgment that road to the regions of the East which your dissensions have closed against me, and permit me speedily to see yourselves and all other peoples rejoicing together, and render due acknowledgment to God in the language of praise and thanksgiving for the restoration of general concord and liberty to all".

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 72:1
verses.text: Chapter LXXIII.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 72:2
verses.text: —The Controversy continues without Abatement, even after the Receipt of This Letter.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 72:3
verses.text: In this manner the pious emperor endeavored by means of the foregoing letter to promote the peace of the Church of God.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 72:4
verses.text: And the excellent man to whom it was intrusted performed his part not merely by communicating the letter itself, but also by seconding the views of him who sent it; for he was, as I have said, in all respects a person of pious character.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 72:5
verses.text: The evil, however, was greater than could be remedied by a single letter, insomuch that the acrimony of the contending parties continually increased, and the effects of the mischief extended to all the Eastern provinces.

verses.name: Life of Constantine Book II 72:6
verses.text: These things jealousy and some evil spirit who looked with an envious eye on the prosperity of the Church, wrought.
